content.protection: 4 bolts, 2 chains w/ rings for anchors.
content.location: First bolted route when approaching from san pedro pullout.

climbs.name: Tickle The Pickle
climbs.fa: Tejal Parikh, Kevin Carmichael, Eric Fazio-Rhicard (1992)

content.description: The shortest and easiest of the climbs on the crag. The climbing is 8ish for most of the climb, including the clip off the "pickle" just left of bolt #3. Just below the anchors there is one reachy move in 5.9 grade.
content.protection: Bolts: well protected. Chains for rappel or lower.
content.location: The second line of bolts from the left side of the formation.

content.description: Fun crimps into blocky corner where stemming and chimney moves keep the climb true to grade. Exiting the overhanging corner is exciting but you'll be rewarded with fantastic holds . Then, you'll get a great semi no hands rest and then easier climbing remains. A final mini crux  guards the last 5 feet to the chains.

San Manuel's twin brother--born of the same devious stone mother, but forged by the elements into a whole different creature. Peculiar and initially incomprehensible sequences, great laybacking, and a mysterious crux await you. Worth a much longer approach... Thanks for another killer line, EFR and Jimbo!
content.location: Branches right where 60 Seconds Over San Manuel goes left.

content.description: Sustained face climbing with sometimes thin feet. The bolt line trends towards the right. You can stem between the face and the uneven ground to start off.
content.protection: Bolts and biners to lower from.
content.location: Starts 3 feet to the right of Tickle the Pickle.

climbs.name: Hadaptation
climbs.fa: Jill Hadap, Jim Scott, Eric Fazio-Rhicard & Jilian Wereb (2014)

content.description: Pull a short burly sequence past two bolts to a large platform.  Rest and continue onward through increasingly difficult edges and small feet.  Finding the optimal sequence may require some work.  Despite its short length and tip-tingling holds, Hadaptation is an enjoyable full value line.
content.protection:
Approximately 7 bolts to leaver biner anchors. 

  When approaching the climb consider using the anchor bolt above the slab to safely reach the start of the route.  The route is short enough that rope can remain tied into the anchor for the duration.
content.location: Located between Second of Doubt and 5 Minutes to Launch, Hadaptation starts at the base of the slab ramp.  The route can be identified by the substantial ledge after the first two bolts.

climbs.name: 62nd Street
climbs.fa: Eric Fazio-Rhicard, Doug Lantz & Diane Vetter (1992)

content.description:
From a large ledge clip the first bolt and move into a shallow dihederal.  Continue to gain ground by stemming, avoiding crumbly flakes, until a series of edges lead up and left.  From a no hands rest, enjoy a tricky but short sequence where one can use the arete, dihederal, or both.  Finish by pulling a small lip with ample jugs. 

  In my opinion 60 Seconds Over San Manuel is both the better and more challenging route.  That said the stemming near the second bolt and crux sequence on 62nd Street are worth sampling.
content.location: 62nd Street is the third route from the left (uphill to downhill).  The route ascends the left-leaning, less-than-vertical face of a dihederal.  The rock is reddish orange.

climbs.name: 60 Seconds Over San Manuel
climbs.fa: Kevin Carmichael, Eric Fazio-Rhicard, et al. (1992)

content.description: This is a fun route with a great view/exposure and a variety of moves. The climbing is easy off the deck but quickly turns into a technical face at approximately bolt #4. Some of the clip stances on the thin face and on the arete require precise use of feet and some smearing. Some of these clips will test the average leader, but all of the falls would be safe. The roof higher up on the climb features some great moves using block holds. Deserves more than the one-star rating given in Squeezing II, IMHO.
content.location: The forth bolted line from the left; located just around the corner from "Tickle The Pickle" and "62nd Street".

climbs.name: 5 Minutes to Launch
climbs.fa: Eric Fazio-Rhicard, Jim Scott, Jesse Schultz, Jonathan Mosher. (2014)

content.description: Route begins with blocky climbing through positive shaped holds and leads into a good rest. The last three bolts are action packed and will lead you to the realization of the route's name meaning.
content.location: Furthest route right on the 60 second wall and just right of Hadaptation. A bolt on the main face allows for a hand line to access  the routes down and below. You'll have enough rope left over to lead Hadaptation and 5 Minutes to Launch.

content.description: A small crag located within throwing distance of the San Pedro Vista pullout. The area has three well-protected sport climbs that are fun and in some cases technically demanding for their grade. The cliff is SE facing and features an exceptional view. The cliff would see more traffic (considering its relatively painless approach) if it featured more moderate climbs.
